SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

Class Dice

java.lang.Object
  Dice

public class Dice
extends Object

So that we can work with theoretical rolls (if we get roll X then ...) There are 2 dice but how about when we roll doubles we think of them as being 4 dice? Or merely use a partialMovesCountDown? Stored in here? There's a parallel array in here marking which dice have been used so far. hmmm, getUsedDiceHowMany & numOfPartialMovesAvail & allDiceAreUsed( ) were working more or less in parallel so I reconciled them by commenting out all "usedDiceHowMany" and kept "allDiceAreUsed( )" for its handiness. The only way you can now decrease the number of PartialMovesAvail is by marking a die as used (which you can do by its die number or by its roll value).

Version:
(2011 Dec 14)
Author:
(Mike Roam)

Constructor Detail

Dice

public Dice()
Default constructor, leaves dice unrolled

Dice

public Dice(Dice other)
Copy Constructor

Dice

public Dice(int newDie1,
            int newDie2)
Constructor for objects of class Dice with only 2 dice. If we get more dice, this has to die. Only accepts rolls of minDiceVal .. maxDiceVal or Dice.UNROLLED Should it accept 0's so I can pass around unrolled dice? I guess so. Figures out rolled status based on the values it gets for the Dice: Either both dice have values in the "rolled" range or both must be UNROLLED: This will throw exception if one diceValue is UNROLLED while other is in rolled range!

Method Detail

allDiceAreUsed

public boolean allDiceAreUsed()
convenience method

allDiceHaveValues

public boolean allDiceHaveValues()
checks for no dice are UNROLLED value

diceRollValuesAvailable

public String diceRollValuesAvailable()
for printing out info about current board, will be list of unused rollValues (not dice nums: e.g. if die1==5 and die2==6, this returns 5,6 if none are used).

getDie

public int getDie(int whichDie)
Dice are named "1", "2" ... up to howManyDice (there is no dice 0!) corresponding to hidden array dice[0], dice[1], respectively

getDie1

public int getDie1()
convenience method. Note: there is no dice0

getDie2

public int getDie2()
convenience method Note: there is a dice2, and there is no dice0

getNumOfPartialMovesAvail

public int getNumOfPartialMovesAvail()
Tells the dice that one of the doublet rolls has been used. Can only be used when dice are doubles, Otherwise use "setUsedDie(int whichDie, true);" to mark a move as used! New approach, 2012apr25: whether you have doubles or not, just tell dice that they're used, which will cause numOfPartialMovesAvail to decrease and DON'T let anybody else decrease it. Making this uncallable to force all calls to become syntax error so I can find and replace them.

getRDice

public Random getRDice()
gets the private "rdice" random number generator. Why should anybody need it? I don't know, but I'm revealing it for unit testing. Might be null!

getRolled

public boolean getRolled()
Supposedly, when rolled is true, all dice have values from minDiceVal..maxDiceVal. Use "roll( )" to roll again, use "reset( )" to blank them all out and set rolled to false.

getUsedDie

public boolean getUsedDie(int newUsedDie)
Tells us if specified die has been used. note: if I get doubles, I'm keeping track of 4 usable dice! Users are speaking in terms of die#1 and die#2 which use our private used[0] and used[1] respectively. And I'm sneaking up on the idea of coding doubles as 4 (identical) dice 1..4, so allowing up to 4 here.

highestUnusedRoll

public int highestUnusedRoll()
returns the value of the highest (roll value) die. will be 0 (??) if dice unrolled? See whichUnusedDieIsHighest( ) to find out which Die holds this value.

isDoubles

public boolean isDoubles()

legitDiceValue

static boolean legitDiceValue(int dieVal)
allows UNROLLED or [minDiceVal to maxDiceVal]

legitDieNum

static boolean legitDieNum(int dieNum)
for specifying which DIE we're talking about, not the value on a face of a die!

lowestUnusedRoll

public int lowestUnusedRoll()
returns the value of the lowest die. will be 0 (??) if dice unrolled? See whichUnusedDieIsHighest( ) to find out which Die holds this value. [ ]This ought to be reconciled with whichUnusedDieIsLowest( ) which says WHICH die is lowest instead of giving its value. They could use the same code and then one returns value instead of position. Ditto for highest.

reset

public void reset()
Puts the dice into unrolled state without dice values, ready for new roll.

resetUsedDice

public void resetUsedDice()
Tells all the dice that they are unused. (For doubles, tells four of them, otherwise just 2) This also resetNumOfPartialMovesAvail( ) so don't make it in turn call us!

roll

public void roll()
I don't want to have a setRolled( ) because I think this is better: this rolls all dice and sets rolled to true. To invalidate the dice, use "reset( )" Unfortunately, if receiving a networked roll, we need to set rolled to true, I guess. Note: there is a version of this for setting two specific dice values "roll(int,int)" which is called by this.

roll

public void roll(int newRoll1,
                 int newRoll2)
changes the (first two) dice to specified values

setDie

public void setDie(int whichDie,
                   int newRoll)
This for setting a specified individual die. Can't use this to set first two dice at once! Use "roll(5,6)" to do that. This expects dice numbers 1 or 2 (not array indices 0,1!!) A changed die is marked as unused, and the DoubletCountdown starts over from the top!

setNumOfPartialMovesAvail

public void setNumOfPartialMovesAvail(int newNumOfPartialMovesAvail)
Sets the numOfPartialMovesAvail to a specified value, unlike resetNumOfPartialMovesAvail( ) which sets it to 2 or 4 as appropriate (and 0 if the dice aren't rolled).

setRolled

public void setRolled(boolean newRolled)
If we want to manually set the dice values, set them all before setting "rolled" to true because I will squawk if some of the dice don't have values (are UNROLLED). It's probably easiest to just call roll(newDie1val, newDie2val) (or do what roll(int,int) does: call roll( ) and then change some of their values. Hmmm, if the dice are already rolled, this has no effect, (doesn't reset the used and numOfPartialMovesAvailcountdown)

setUsedDie

public void setUsedDie(int newUsedDie,
                       boolean newUsedTF)
Tell a specific die (by die#, not by value) that it has been used. If this is news (if the die is not already marked used) then this decreases numOfPartialMovesAvail (and formerly increased usedDiceHowMany). doMove and doPartialMove might be calling this when they know which die they're using, but now that there is a setUsedValue( ) method, they could call setUsedValue( ) instead of this setUsedDie( ), without caring which die holds the used value. Handy!

setUsedValue

public void setUsedValue(int whichVal)
Suppose I roll 5,6 and want to say that I've used the “5” unlike “setUsedDie”, this works from roll value, Not which die you’re talking about. If we have doubles (e.g. 5,5) then it doesn't matter which we use, so we can use one that isn’t used yet OUT OF FOUR. gy suggestion 2012 (he’s full of ’em!): return a boolean indicating success. hmmm, if Dice were a hashmap or something we could quick search for whichVal.

shortString

public String shortString()
merely returns 3,1 or 2,2 unlike toString which returns all kinds of info including how many partialMoves remaining and which dice are used

toString

public String toString()
returns the dice roll values (only 2) and tells which dice have been used, numbered 1,2,3,4 not 0,1,2,3 ?? Will this malfunction on doubles?

Overrides:
toString in class Object

whichDieHasValue

public int whichDieHasValue(int rollVal)
Special for doubles: every die has same value, so just returning "1" Be careful about using this with doubles since it won't correspond to which potential moves are which. Note: in the outside world the die numbers are 1,2[,3,4 for doubles] but in here the arrays are numbered 0,1[,2,3].

Returns:
which die has this value. NO_SUCH_DIE (-9) if none.

whichDieIsUnused

public int whichDieIsUnused()
returns the first unused die number (WHICH die, not its roll value), range 1..maxMovesCount working its way up from lowest numbered dice

whichUnusedDieIsHighest

public int whichUnusedDieIsHighest()
unlike highestRoll, this tells us WHICH Unused die has the highest value. Will fail on doubles.

whichUnusedDieIsLowest

public int whichUnusedDieIsLowest()
unlike lowestRoll, this tells us WHICH Unused die has the lowest value.
